title: general: apply clippy lints
body:
updated the crates to the 2021 edition due to the new formatting lints in `panic!` and `assert!` macros.  
If preferred I can try to isolate the fixes to only assert #405 passes.

title: sctp: set verification tag to zero on the INIT packet.
body:
Hi! We have been getting:
```
[2023-01-23T20:41:10Z WARN  webrtc_sctp::association::association_internal] [] failed validating packet init chunk expects a verification tag of 0 on the packet when out-of-the-blue
[2023-01-23T20:41:10Z WARN  webrtc::peer_connection::peer_connection_internal] failed to open data channel: there already exists a stream with identifier 
```
on the [test-plans](https://github.com/libp2p/test-plans/) CI for the ping interop tests between two node using the `WebRTC` transport which uses `webrtc-rs` underneath, [see here](https://github.com/libp2p/test-plans/actions/runs/3990270518/jobs/6843709448#step:11:9403) for a reproduction which then breaks the test as the node fails to open the data channel. 

While trying to debug the issue I found that when `webrtc_sctp::association::association_internal` sends the `INIT` chunk via `send_init`, the `verification_tag` was copied from `self.verification_tag`. Per the [RFC](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4960#section-8.5.1) and as `check_packet` rightfully checks:

https://github.com/webrtc-rs/webrtc/blob/95f8c26007a8f6c8354cb7b56385e5619a534ba7/sctp/src/packet.rs#L225-L227

It should always be `0`.

My feeling without knowing much about the protocol nor the implementation is that sometimes `handle_init` is called first and then updates `self.verification_tag` to the received `Initiate Tag` then when calling `send_init` again `self.verification_tag` is sent with the `Initiate Tag`.
This PR tries to address by hardcoding the `verification_tag` field to `0` on the `send_init` 

Thanks

title: ice: Remove unused MulticastDnsMode:Unspecified variant.
body: Seems to be used only for converting to `::QueryOnly`

title: Async refactor
body: This PR removes unnecessary async.

title: Custom `RTCRtpTransceiver` creating
body: This PR provides API for creating custom `RTCRtpSender`, `RTCRtpReceiver` and `RTCRtpTransceiver` and adding `RTCRtpTransceiver` to `RTCPeerConnection`.

title: sctp: fix 'attempt to add with overflow' panic in dev profile
body:
Fixes an unwrapped add that only affects programs compiled in the dev profile ([release profile naturally wraps](https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/ch03-02-data-types.html#integer-overflow)).

This issue should not affect applications built in release, but is surprising in dev nonetheless.  As this is my first contribution, I'm not too familiar with the codebase yet.  My primary fix is on line 270, while I only suspect line 318 also qualifies. I have not reproduced this issue for 318 and not certain how to test either issue directly -- any guidance here is appreciated.

Partial stacktrace of the panic:

```
thread 'async-compat/tokio-1' panicked at 'attempt to add with overflow', /home/cscorley/.cargo/registry/src/github.com-1ecc6299db9ec823/webrtc-sctp-0.7.0/src/queue/reassembly_queue.rs:270:17
stack backtrace:
   0: rust_begin_unwind
             at /rustc/90743e7298aca107ddaa0c202a4d3604e29bfeb6/library/std/src/panicking.rs:575:5
   1: core::panicking::panic_fmt
             at /rustc/90743e7298aca107ddaa0c202a4d3604e29bfeb6/library/core/src/panicking.rs:65:14
   2: core::panicking::panic
             at /rustc/90743e7298aca107ddaa0c202a4d3604e29bfeb6/library/core/src/panicking.rs:115:5
   3: webrtc_sctp::queue::reassembly_queue::ReassemblyQueue::read
   4: webrtc_sctp::stream::Stream::read_sctp::{{closure}}
```

Other than adding a `constraints-v0.1.0`git tag for the release commit, are there any other release steps I should be aware of when doing an initial release of `webrtc-constraints`?

title: Update sponsor image/URL in README.md
body: Hi there! Glad to be a sponsor. I've updated the image to be a better quality one, and updated the URL. Thanks!

title: Prevent loss of initial packet(s) in RTP streams
body:
The method by which we detected non-signaled SSRCs would silently drop a
few packets. This is particularly problematic for a video stream since
these initial packets usually contain the first part of a keyframe to
start the stream.

See: #386 


**Note:** The first packet read for each RTP stream is not processed by interceptors unfortunately.

title: Unify `assert_eq!(…)`/`assert_ne!(…)` to take args in order of `…!(actual, expected)`
body:
While there isn't an explicit convention for this in Rust the stdlib docs all use `assert_eq!(actual, expected)`/`assert_ne!(actual, expected)` —as do the [Rust by Example](https://doc.rust-lang.org/rust-by-example/testing/unit_testing.html) and [The Rust Programming Language](https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/ch11-01-writing-tests.html) <sup>([*](https://github.com/rust-lang/book/pull/3497))</sup> books— making it a sort of implicit convention.

The project contains over 2000 occurrences of the pattern `/assert_(ne|eq|ok|err)!/`, so this PR is clearly a best-effort attempt to unify the arg order. There are no doubt instances that I missed either due to inattentiveness after having gone through thousands of lines of code, or ambiguous argument names.

title: Fix rustc/clippy warnings
body:
Before: 400 warnings
After: 6 warnings

title: Improve the markdown of our README files
body: See the commit messages for the individual improvements.

* Fixes the min-version check in github actions.
* Run the same version aem, aem-gcm, sha1, sha2 and hmac across the board.
* Fix deprecations arising in chrono

title: sctp: remove unnecessary drops and use precise padding
body:
Refs https://github.com/webrtc-rs/webrtc/pull/364 and https://github.com/webrtc-rs/webrtc/pull/367

cc @KillingSpark

title: Outbound sequence number overriding
body: Move outbound sequence number overriding on the transport level to prevent `SRTP` crashing on the `RTCRtpSender::replace_track()` call.

title: Make RTCRtpTransceiver (Sender, Receiver) spec-compliant
body: This PR reworked Sender and Receiver on Transceiver to comply with specification.

title: Make RTCRtpTransceiver.mid spec-compliant
body:
The current implementation is:

```
pub struct RTCRtpTransceiver {
    mid: Mutex<String>,                           //atomic.Value
    sender: Mutex<Option<Arc<RTCRtpSender>>>,     //atomic.Value
    receiver: Mutex<Option<Arc<RTCRtpReceiver>>>, //atomic.Value
    ...
}
```

Essentially, the empty string is used instead of `None` (`Option<String>`).
This PR makes the behavior of `mid` explicitly optional, and also replaces `Mutex` with `OnceCell`.

title: Fix over-NACK due to NackPair lost_packets not resetting
[SCTP] limit the bytes in the PendingQueue by using a semaphore
body:
As discussed in #360 the pending queue can grow indefinitly if the sender writes packets faster than the association is able to transmit them.

This PR solves this by enforcing a limit on the pendig queue. This blocks the sender until enough space is free.

title: Adjust logging levels in mDNS
body: Before this module would `info` log and every packet it received. It has been updated to match the `ice` module and use the trace level for incoming packets.

title: [SCTP] improve payload queue push performance
body:
As discussed in #360 Gathering packets to send is a big chunk of the work the Association::write_loop is doing while in a critical section.

This PR improves the performance of this by making the payload queue more performant to push to.

Previously this did a full mergesort (O(n*log(n))) on all the in-flight TSNs, now it does a binary search (O(log(n)))

title: [SCTP] Optimize sctp packet marshalling
body:
As discussed in #360 the marshalling code has become a bottle neck in high bandwidth sending situations. I found two places that had a big effect on the performance, the hot path for this situation is marshalling packets with exactly one data chunk in them.

After this PR the marshalling is largely dominated by the CRC32 calculation which is... not easy to speed up.

title: [SCTP] Associtation lock contention
body:
As discussed in #360 the lock on the internal association is very contended in high send-bandwidth situations. This PR achieves two things:

1. Pull the marshalling of packets outside of the critical section thus reducing the time the lock is taken by the write loop
2. Schedule the marshalling and sending as a new tokio::task::Task which makes tokio schedule this on another thread allowing the read loop to make progress in parallel while the write loop is working on that

This in itself does not really increase the bandwidth but with improvements to the marshalling code itself gains can be head now, that were previously (at least partially) blocked by the lock contention.

It should also improve situations where both sides send a lot of data because then the write and read loops would both be very busy and fighting for the lock even more.

title: webrtc-constraints: A complete and spec-compliant `SelectSettings` algorithm implementation
body:
Hi @rainliu,

this PR replaces the existing and incomplete and spec-non-compliant implementation of `webrtc-media` with a complete and —most importantly!— spec-compliant, while extracting the code into a separate `webrtc-constraints` crate.

## What does it do?

The PR implements the `SelectSettings` algorithm as defined in the [Media Capture and Streams](https://www.w3.org/TR/mediacapture-streams/) W3C spec.

The API is used like this:

```rust
// A set of constraints supported by the user-agent:
let supported_constraints: MediaTrackSupportedConstraints = ...;

// A list of possible settings supported by the user-agent:
let possible_settings: Vec<MediaTrackSettings> = ...; 

// Ideal settings used for tie-breaking:
let ideal_settings: MediaTrackSettings = ...; 

// A desired tie-breaking policy (these can be fully customized!), such as "closest-to-ideal":
let policy = ClosestToIdealPolicy::new(ideal_settings, &supported_constraints);

// A set of user-provided "basic" and/or "advanced" constraints:
let constraints: MediaTrackConstraints = ...;

// Lowering of constraints:
let resolved_constraints: ResolvedMediaTrackConstraints = constraints.into_resolved();
let sanitized_constraints: SanitizedMediaTrackConstraints = constraints.into_sanitized(&supported_constraints);

// Select settings candidates:
let selected_settings_candidates: Vec<&MediaTrackSettings> = select_settings_candidates(
    &possible_settings,
    &sanitized_constraints,
    DeviceInformationExposureMode::Protected,
)?;

// Select settings:
let selected_settings: &MediaTrackSettings = policy.select_candidate(selected_settings_candidates);
```

In addition to its rich, yet safe and fool-proof Rust API it also provides support for parsing settings/constraints from their JSON representation (optional, via `serde` feature) for easy integration with existing JS-based interfaces.

## Why do we need this?

Well, my original implementation of settings/constraints (`webrtc_media::track::{settings, constraints}`) has a couple of problems:
- it is **incomplete**: it doesn't support "advanced" constraints, for example.
- it is **not spec-compliant**, which is in part due to being incomplete, but it also by ignoring some of the spec requirements
- it is **getting in the way of usage**, due to some unfortunate API decisions I had made with it
- it **does not support interfacing with JSON**-encoded settings/constraints, thus making it hard to integrate with existing web APIs

This new implementation aims to fix these! It is —to the best of my knowledge—:
- a **complete implementation** of the `SelectSettings` algorithm and corresponding types
- **spec-compliant**, afaict
- designed with **versatility** and **ergonomics** in mind
- parsing settings/constraints from **JSON is supported** (optional)

## How does it work?

The [Media Capture and Streams](https://www.w3.org/TR/mediacapture-streams/) W3C spec defines a very flexible structure for specifying media constraints. This results in somewhat complex type-definitions in Rust, since there are a lot of edge-cases to consider.

In order to allow for parsing the flexible JSON structure, while also keeping redundancy in the algorithm implementation to a minimum it implements a kind of lowering pipeline (similar to those found in modern compilers):

```
MediaTrackConstraint
└──▸ ResolvedMediaTrackConstraint
     └──▸ SanitizedMediaTrackConstraint
```

### `MediaTrackConstraint`

`MediaTrackConstraint` can express empty constraints, bare value constraints or "standard" constraints.

### `ResolvedMediaTrackConstraint`

By lowering `MediaTrackConstraint` to a `ResolvedMediaTrackConstraint` (via `into_resolved()`/`to_resolved()`, based on a `MediaTrackConstraintResolutionStrategy` of either `BareToIdeal` or `BareToExact`) any bare value constraints get resolved to their corresponding "standard" constraint representation.

### `SanitizedMediaTrackConstraint`

By lowering `ResolvedMediaTrackConstraint` to a `SanitizedMediaTrackConstraint` (via `into_sanitized()`/`to_sanitized()`, based on a set of supported constraints) any empty or unsupported constraints get dropped.

This allows for the `SelectSettings` algorithm to only deal with "standard" constraints (i.e. `SanitizedMediaTrackConstraint`), thus greatly simplifying the implementation.

## Safety

- The code does not make use of `unsafe { … }` whatsoever.
- The code handles `NaN` values without crashing.
- The code makes minimal use of `.expect()`/`.unwrap()`.
- The code is covered by hundreds of unit tests checking for edge-cases.

## Tests?

The crate comes with 240+ unit tests (making up about 20% of the total code) covering the implementation of the fitness-distance function, the select-settings algorithm, as well as the json parsing, and more …

## Why a separate crate?

1. The crate is just shy over 9000 lines of Rust (out of which ~1800 lines/~20% are for tests) and self-contained.
2. The implementation has potential use-cases unrelated to `webrtc-media` as Google's `libwebrtc` lacks an implementation of `SelectSettings`.

```
===============================================================================
 Language            Files        Lines         Code     Comments       Blanks
===============================================================================
 TOML                    1           23           18            1            4
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 Rust                   56         9136         7666          385         1085
 |- Markdown            28          553            0          411          142
 (Total)                           9689         7666          796         1227
===============================================================================
 Total                  57         9159         7684          386         1089
===============================================================================
```

title: Make `RTCPeerConnection::on_track` spec-compliant
Try fixing #347
body: Fixing #347 as suggested by [k0nserv](https://github.com/k0nserv).

title: implement from and tryfrom string traits for SessionDescription
Release minor versions of data, sctp and dtls crates
add `PendingQueue::append`
body:
which appends chunks to the back of the pending queue.

Consider the following two simultaneous calls to `send_payload_data`:

```
  1. [beginning_fragment1, data2, data3, ending_fragment4]
  2. [beginning_fragment5, data6, data7, ending_fragment8]
```

If `push` is used, due to individual locks, it's possible to end up with:

```
  [beginning_fragment1, data2, beginning_fragment5, data3, data6, ending_fragment4,
     data6, data7, ending_fragment8]
```

This will result in wrong data received by the remote.

title: [sctp] make `write` sync
body: There's no reason for it to be async because it just buffers the data in memory (actual IO is happening in a separate thread).

title: [DTLS] Use `RSA_PKCS1_1024_8192_SHA256_FOR_LEGACY_USE_ONLY` for short signatures
body: Will fix #339

title: [PollStream/PollDataChannel] do not loose bytes
body:
Returning `Poll::Ready(Ok(n))` when `write_fut` is `Some` is incorrect since `buf` already contains new data and we should instead always return `Poll::Ready(Ok(buf.len()))` and update `write_fut`.

In the future, if/when we make `write` synchronous, this whole block could be simplified to just contain a single call (1 line) to `write`. See #344

title: PollStream/PollDataChannel: flush before shutting down
body:
"Invocation of a shutdown implies an invocation of flush. Once this method returns Ready it implies that a flush successfully happened before the shutdown happened. That is, callers don’t need to call flush before calling shutdown. They can rely that by calling shutdown any pending buffered data will be written out."

https://docs.rs/tokio/1.21.2/tokio/io/trait.AsyncWrite.html#tymethod.poll_shutdown

title: Remove unnecessary async in public API
body:
> mind if i create a PR that makes all callback setters (e.g. RTCPeerConnection::on_ice_candidate()) non async? Currently callbacks are stored behind tokio::Mutex'es, i believe that ArcSwap can be used here, so we can use atomic load/store. It wont affect performance in any way, just some quality of life improvements.

> All good with me. I'd like to get rid of  tokio::Mutex, replacing it with sync variants, where that's possible

So i've refactored all public callback setters here. 

Regarding removing `tokio::Mutex`es that you've mentioned, well, i've replaced some of those, but i don't want this PR to become even bigger, and it would be nice if you provide some feedback first. I've used both `ArcSwap` and `std::Mutex`, i guess its ok to use blocking mutex in simple cases, when you don't need to hold it, e.g. copy, store, swap, take one-liners. I will prepare follow-up PRs on this issue if this PR looks good to you.

And one more thing regarding the callbacks, maybe it makes sense to make them just dumb `Box<dyn Fn(_)>`? So `Box<dyn (FnMut(ConnectionState) -> Pin<Box<dyn Future<Output = ()> + Send + 'static>>) + Send + Sync>` => `Box<dyn (Fn(ConnectionState)) + Send + Sync>`.  Yeah, that might hurt users in some rare cases, but it would make everything simpler.

ack @k0nserv

title: Add MSRV policy and update MSRV to 1.60.0
Support providing RTP extensions in local tracks
body:
- Add generic `rtp::extension::HeaderExtension`
- Add a method to write extensions for local tracks

title: [peer_connection] RTCCertificate: rework `from_pem` and `serialize_pem`
body:
which makes it possible to serialise and persist a certificate to disk. Both methods require `pem` feature to be enabled (I think having a feature is good since I don't expect many people to use persistent certificate). Previous implementation of `from_pem` was incorrect. It used a given certificate as a CA (hence the 2nd argument) instead of just using the certificate directly (see the related TODO in tests where `cert1 == cert3` should be matching).

API reflects one in Pion - https://github.com/pion/webrtc/blob/master/certificate.go#L179 (see `CertificateFromPEM` and `PEM` functions).

Also

- modify `RTCCertificate::get_fingerprints` to return `Vec<Fingerprint>`. No need for `Result`.
- refactor `dtls::crypto::Certificate`
- fixes TODO where two certificates should be equal when `from_pem` is being used.

title: Marshalled extension types derive Serialize/Deserialize
body: To make them more usable for the consumer of these types.

title: [TURN] Fix server relay UDP port not release problem.
body:
On our servers, we found that after the TURN service runs for a long time, there will be a large number of UDP ports that are not released.

We found that the reason is that after the `packet_handler` task is started, if the client no longer uses the UDP connection, `relay_socket.recv_from` will never return. So we add a 10-second timeout here to check whether the allocation has been dropped every 10 seconds.

Fixes https://github.com/webrtc-rs/webrtc/issues/232
Refs https://github.com/webrtc-rs/turn/issues/13

title: Update README examples link following monorepo move
body: The link still points to the archived repo. I've updated it to point to the same README in the monorepo

title: Don't generate empty TWCC feedback packets
body:
The previous version of this code would very often generate a feedback
packet with no chunks. These packets would be ignored by libWebRTC which
logs an error message saying:

```
Buffer too small (16 bytes) to fit a FeedbackPacket. Minimum size = 18
```

When receiving such a packet.

It also felt weird to clear the received packets when no chunks were
generated for those packets.

title: add support for the telephone-event codec
body:
Hi,

This just adds a mime type and resolves it to the G7xxPayloader. 

Telephone event packets are just a 4 byte payload, and I could add an even simpler payloader but I think the G7xxPayloader does the right thing here, even if the name is not really fitting this usecase.

Any other places this new codec would need mentioning?

title: One single direction per extmap
body:
SDP has the syntax: `a=extmap:<id>/<direction> <uri>`

The /<direction> part is optional (and rarely seen it in the wild).

The current MediaEngine API makes it seem like it's possible to provide many directions for each map (it takes a Vec). This commit changes that sov only single optional direction can be provided.

This simplifies internal matching logic and fixes a bug where setting the transceiver direction `inactive`, would (incorrectly) result in no extmaps matching for the m-line.

title: Remove plan-b support
body:
M96 was released 2021-11-15. All Chrome releases since then have been (largely) without plan-b support.

The SDP used to establish a connection in WebRTC has a non-standard dialect: Plan B. [Removal timeline][1]:

* M93: Exception thrown in Canary.
* M96: Exception thrown in Beta and Stable.

[1]: https://chromestatus.com/feature/5823036655665152

title: Fix IP filter
body: The logic was wrong and would actually remove many IPs.

title: Pause in TrackBinding when direction is not send
body: When direction is such that we are not sending. The writing of RTP packets is stopped already in TrackBinding to avoid allocating sequence numbers when they are not needed.

title: Improve Sample Builder padding handling for static streams
body:
Improve Sample Builder handling of padding packets

When sending video streams that are fairly static, such as a screen
share of an inactive screen, libWebRTC will insert padding RTP packets.
These were not correctly handled by sample builder, because of this
`SampleBuilder` would throw away packets carrying actual media.

There was also a bug where dropping packets because the sample head was
not at a partition start would double count the dropped packets(once in
`build_sample` and once in `purge_buffers`.


## Example

As an example libWebRTC will send streams like this:

```
p1(t=1, start=true)
p2(t=1)
p3(t=1)
p4(t=1, marker=true)
p5(t=1, padding=true)
p6(t=1, padding=true)
p7(t=1, padding=true)
p8(t=2, start=true, marker=true)
p9(t=2, padding=true)
p10(t=2, padding=true)
p11(t=2, padding=true)
```

Prior to this commit `SampleBuilder` would build a sample out of `p1..=p4`
then drop `p5..=p8`. This would mean the bit of media data in `p8` would
be incorrectly dropped.

The reason for dropping `p5..=p8` is that `p5` is not at a partition head
and `p8` is incorrectly identified as the end of the sample, the real
end is `p7`.

With this commit `SampleBuilder` will build sample out of `p1..=p4`,
identify `p5..=p7` as padding and drop these packets, and build a sample
for `p8`.

title: Rework data-channels-flow-control example
body:
All examples and tests should be reworked like this one to make it possible to rework inner callback representation.

Under "like this one" I mean reworking at least callbacks in examples and tests, so there is no logic outside of async blocks, only state management.

I want to merge this into master, and not into feature/rework-callbacks, because in this example old callback representation is used, it does not break anything and will not prevent the release in any way.

If I rework other examples, I will also use the old callback representation, since the examples are generally poorly written. It is too difficult to move them to a new representation at the moment, I will still have to rewrite them from scratch. So I don't want to rewrite and move them to a new representation at the same time.

title: Add IP filter to WebRTC SettingEngine and ICE AgentConfig
body: Changes ported from https://github.com/pion/webrtc/pull/2316

title: Handle empty RTP packets in Sample Builder
body:
libWebRTC, among others, will sometime send padding RTP packets to keep send rates steady. When they do the packets are sent after a complete sequence of RTP packets that form a Sample/GOP/Frame. Example:

* P0, Timestamp=1, Start
* P1, T=1
* P2, T=1, End(RTP Marker Bit set)
* P3, T=1, Padding
* P4, T=1, Padding
* P5, T=2, Start
* P6, T=2 End

Here, when building a sample using the packets P5 and P6 we'll have `prev_dropped_packets = 2`, however these dropped packets are inconsequential as they don't carry media. The stream of samples is unbroken, despite having dropped some packets. With the introduction of `prev_padding_packets` it's possible to distinguish between dropped packets that are likely to break the sample stream and these unimportant padding packets

title: [ice-restart example]: directory for index.html uses examples/examples
body: To fix a 404 not found error when running the example.

title: Rework almost all callbacks
body:
Almost all callbacks, whose name matches On*Fn pattern, reworked, except for those that were skipped with a comment why (check commits "Skip <callback_name>").
Callback representation reverted to `Box::new(|| async {})` because of `webrtc_ice::agent::agent_vnet_test::on_connected()` that returns boxed closure (we can't return non boxed closure).

title: Remove video/rtx codecs
body:
We don't actually support handling RTX on a distinct SSRC and declaring
these causes Chrome(and maybe others) to not sent retransmissions within
the existing RTP stream. This all means that even if we emit NACKs the
resulting retransmissions will simply be ignored.

title: Rework OnBufferedAmountLowFn callback representation
body:
With this minor changes, you can now provide `|| async {}` as OnBufferedAmountLowFn callback instead of 
`Box::new(|| Box::pin(async {}))`.

title: Promote create_agent lock to top of function, to avoid race condition
body:
create_agent is called multiple times from multiple threads, however, it is not locked properly.

The code as written before:
1) Acquire lock
2) Check for early exit if agent is already in a usable state
3) Release lock
4) Build agent config
5) Acquire lock
6) Create agent and update value stored
7) Release lock

The issue is that two threads can get to step 4 at the same time, and hence the second one to complete step 6, obliterates the agent of the other.

Since building the agent config is cheap, it is cleaner to simply acquire the lock, and not release it until the function completes. So:

1) Acquire lock
2) Check for early exit if agent is already in a usable state
3) Build agent config
4) Create agent and update value stored
5) Release lock

---

An alternative is to do the early exit check once again after step 5, as:
1) Acquire lock
2) Check for early exit if agent is already in a usable state
3) Release lock
4) Build agent config
5) Acquire lock
6) Check for early exit if agent is already in a usable state
7) Create agent and update value stored
8) Release lock

But simply promoting the lock seems like a cleaner, less error prone choice.

---

We were seeing this race condition trigger about 0.1% of the time on certain setups.

title: Get allocations info
body:
Add possibility to get information about `Allocation`s with `Server::get_allocations_info` method. This method returns `HashMap<FiveTuple, AllocationInfo>`.
Now `AllocationInfo` provides `five_tuple`, `name` and `relayed_bytes`, but can be extended.

title: Implement remote outbound stats
body: Also refactors stats fairly significantly in preparation for this.

title: Fix async-global-executor
body: Build broke on 1.57.0 due to 2.3.0 being released

title: Implement Remote Inbound Stats
body:
I had to refactor the stats collection to split inbound and outbound
stats from one-another.

title: relax regex version requirement
body: some projects like https://github.com/bheisler/criterion.rs depend on regex: `1.3`. I don't see why 1.6 have to be a requirement.

title: mdns: get_interface_addr_for_ip once per query
body:
Closes https://github.com/webrtc-rs/mdns/issues/23

Port of https://github.com/webrtc-rs/mdns/pull/25

title: Fix current direction update when applying answer
body:
When applying an answer from the remote the value of
`current_direction`was correctly update, but the process to trigger any
side effect was incorrectly using `direction` instead of
`current_direction` to determine the previous direction.

title: Add concurrency limit in CI
body:
With this change we'll cancel in-progress workflows when new code is
pushed.

title: Disable some flaky tests on windows
Add method to delete `allocation` by `username`
body:
## Synopsis

We are currently trying to replace [Coturn](https://github.com/coturn/coturn) with this implementation. But currently it does not have alternatives to specific Coturn's functionality e.g. providing metrics, TCP fallback, external management capabilities. So we want to elaborate on that starting with exposing some management interfaces. 

Here is the Coturn's telnet protocol for reference:

```
TURN Server
Coturn-4.5.2 'dan Eider'

  ?, h, help - print this text

  quit, q, exit, bye - end CLI session

  stop, shutdown, halt - shutdown TURN Server

  pc - print configuration

  sr <realm> - set CLI session realm

  ur - unset CLI session realm

  so <origin> - set CLI session origin

  uo - unset CLI session origin

  tc <param-name> - toggle a configuration parameter
     (see pc command output for togglable param names)

  cc <param-name> <param-value> - change a configuration parameter
     (see pc command output for changeable param names)

  ps [username] - print sessions, with optional exact user match

  psp <usernamestr> - print sessions, with partial user string match

  psd <file-name> - dump ps command output into file on the TURN server system

  pu [udp|tcp|dtls|tls]- print current users

  lr - log reset

  aas ip[:port} - add an alternate server reference
  das ip[:port] - delete an alternate server reference
  atas ip[:port] - add a TLS alternate server reference
  dtas ip[:port] - delete a TLS alternate server reference

  cs <session-id> - cancel session, forcefully

```

The particular function that we need is being able to forcefully close specific allocations.

## Solution

Add the ability to communicate with the applications main loop, running in the `Server::read_loop()` method.

Add `Server.delete_allocations_by_username(&self, username: String)` function.

Also, there are some low-hanging fruits in terms of optimizations, so this pull request includes minor refactoring aimed at improving overall performance.

Fix test_receiver_interceptor_jitter on Ubuntu
body:
A [previous fix][0] for this issue has proven not to work. With this we
make time entirely deterministic in this test, a practice that we should
use in other tests if successful here.

[0]: https://github.com/webrtc-rs/interceptor/commit/0a2e942e0591e45bfeba6eec7f18960f96e3c5ba

title: Debug current dir in sctp fuzz tests
[DTLS] Add NamedCurve::P384
Specify both path and version in crate deps
body:
Cargo allows specifying both a `path` and `version` for dependencies,
doing this makes publishing easier.

> It is possible to specify both a registry version and a git or path
> location. The git or path dependency will be used locally (in which
> case the version is checked against the local copy), and when
> published to a registry like crates.io, it will use the registry
> version. Other combinations are not allowed.

_From [The Cargo Book][0]_

[0]: https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/specifying-dependencies.html#multiple-locations

title: Fix datachannel id setting for 0.5.0 release
body: Per comments [here](https://github.com/webrtc-rs/webrtc/issues/235), this prevents a `RTCDataChannel id` from updating on open unless a) the value was not negotiated, and b) the value is equal to zero (i.e., the `null` value by existing crate convention). This fixes most of the existing error cases and does not introduce new ones. It does, however, miss one specific case (where a user creates a non-negotiated data channel with `id = 0`). Fixing that case would be a sizeable refactor. There is a TODO comment for addressing it.

title: Pause RTP writing if direction indicates it
body:
Currently if `RTCRtpTransceiver::direction` is set to a valueq which
doesn't allow sending data, we happily keep sending data if the user
does `write_sample` or `write_rtp`.

This changes so that any writes are just dropped as long as the
direction doesn't permit sending.

title: Fix recent clippy lints
body:
Rust 1.63.0 introduces new clippy lints that were failing CI, this fixes
them.

title: Revert "base id updating on whether it's been negotiated, not on its …
body:
…value (#226)"

This reverts commit 823c3f80f13b40a7454efebc8f40ddbc04c24099.

As pointed out in [the original PR](https://github.com/webrtc-rs/webrtc/pull/226#issuecomment-1202028922), this commit broke the API guarantees we had before. I don't think I have time right now to fix this properly, but maybe @stuqdog does?

title: base id updating on whether it's been finalized, not on its value
body: Currently, a data channel id is updated on open if it's set to 0. This can be a problem if a data channel is created through a peer connection with the id intentionally set to 0. This pr adds a new field to `DataChannelParameters` and `RTCDataChannelInit` (`id_finalized`), which is set to `true` when a user intentionally provides an id, allowing us to respect that id choice on data channel open regardless of its value.
